title: Hearing Instrument Troubleshooting Using Real Ear Measurements
chief_complaint: My hearing aids sound muffled, unclear, and dull. I have trouble understanding what people are saying, and the devices whistle, so I hardly use them anymore.

problem_summary.onset: Recent, following purchase of devices in her former community.
problem_summary.course: No significant improvement since purchase; infrequent use due to lack of benefit.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Feedback (whistling), lack of clarity, difficulty in noise.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Patient has stopped using the devices regularly due to minimal benefit.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Seeking a second opinion to see if the devices can be improved.

history.present_illness: Patient was fitted with open-fit BTEs bilaterally at a different center before moving to the area. She reports 'muffled' sound quality and feedback. She feels the devices provide minimal benefit.
history.otologic_history: Unremarkable otoscopy. No change in hearing sensitivity perceived over past several years.
history.medical_psych_history: No change in health status since acquiring hearing instruments.
history.prior_management: Fitted with open-fit BTEs. Previous audiological results provided.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Mild sloping to moderately severe sensorineural hearing loss bilaterally. Symmetrical configuration.

numeric_results.Bone_Conduction: Consistent with sensorineural loss (no air-bone gaps).

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: SRTs consistent with pure-tone averages. WRS reveals slight difficulty in ability to recognize speech at MCL.

tests.name: Electroacoustic Analysis
tests.key_findings: Devices functioning appropriately compared to manufacturer ANSI specifications. No distortion or internal noise.

tests.name: Real Ear Measures (REM)
tests.key_findings: Significant under-amplification relative to DSL v5.0 targets, particularly in high frequencies (>2000 Hz). Audibility limited to 250-1500 Hz for soft speech.

numeric_results.High_Frequency_Audibility: Insufficient above 2000 Hz for soft, average, and loud inputs.

tests.name: Feedback Analysis
tests.key_findings: Maximum stable gain was significantly lower than available gain due to open-vent condition, preventing adequate high-frequency amplification without feedback.

tests.name: Real Ear Measures (REM)
tests.key_findings: After changing to closed domes and reprogramming, REARs showed improved audibility and a closer match to DSL v5.0 targets. Occlusion effect test showed no issues.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with a mild sloping to moderately severe sensorineural hearing loss bilaterally. Her existing open-fit BTEs were technically functional but poorly fitted, providing insufficient high-frequency gain due to feedback limitations imposed by the open domes. Switching to closed domes allowed for increased high-frequency gain to meet DSL v5.0 targets without feedback or occlusion issues.
counseling_points: Your hearing aids are working correctly, but they weren't tuned to give you the high-pitch sounds you need to hear clearly.
The 'open' ear tips you were using let sound escape, which caused the whistling and prevented us from turning up the volume where you need it most.
We have switched you to 'closed' domes. This keeps the sound in your ear, stops the whistling, and allows us to make speech sound much sharper.
I have verified these new settings with a microphone in your ear to ensure you are getting the correct amount of sound for your specific hearing loss.
notes_for_actor: Portray a patient who is frustrated and skeptical. You spent money on these devices recently and they don't work.
Describe the sound as 'muffled' or 'dull' repeatedly.
Initially, express concern that 'closing' your ear with a new dome might make your voice sound funny (occlusion), but accept the change when tested.
